title: PhD. Candidate, Finance
description_1: Dissertation: 'Three Essays on Financial Innovation'

title: Mag. rer. soc. oec., Economics
description_1: Thesis: 'Money Creation, Debt Dynamics and Financial Stability'

title: Bakk. rer. soc. oec., Economics
description_1: Theses: 'Inflexible Wages and Prices in Keynes' and New Keynesian Theory' and 'Post Crisis - The Taxation of the Financial Sector'

title: Crowdfunding with Private Consumer Valuations
description_1: I characterize the profit-maximizing crowdfunding mechanism when consumers have private information about their product valuations.
description_2: I presented the paper at the Second Toronto FinTech Conference and the 2018 and 2019 VGSF Conference.

title: Trust Takes Time: Limits to Arbitrage in Decentralized Markets
loc: with Nikolaus Hautsch and Stefan Voigt
description_1: We demonstrate how blockchain-based settlement introduces a novel friction to cross-market trading.
description_2: I presented the paper at the 2018 Crypto Valley Blockchain Conference, the 2018 Finance Research Day in Graz, the 2019 Financial Intermediation Research Society Conference and the 2019 European Finance Association Meeting.

title: Perceived Precautionary Savings Motives: Evidence from FinTech
loc: with Francesco D'Acunto, Thomas Rauter and Michael Weber
description_1: We show that households with higher liquid wealth behave as if they faced strong precautionary savings motives even if no observables suggest they should do so.

title: Fishing with Pearls: Fishing with Pearls: The Value of Lending Relationships with Prestigious Firms
loc: with Alexander Mürmann and Thomas Rauter
description_1: We show that lenders compete for prestigious borrowers and offer lower upfront fees to initiate lending relationships with them.
description_2: I presented the paper at the 2018 Financial Intermediation Research Society Conference

title: The Dark Side of Liquid Bonds in Fire Sales
loc: with Alexander Mürmann and Maria Chaderina
description_1: We argue that institutional investors fail to internalize the negative impact they exert on other market participants in fire sales.

title: Why Do Mutual Funds Hold Cash?
description_1: We argue that mutual fund managers sell illiquid assets in response to redemptions to preserve the optimal fund size.

title: Prae-Doc Reseacher
loc: WU (Vienna University of Economics and Business)
description_1: FWF-financed project assistant at the Vienna Graduate School of Finance from September 2015 to July 2019. My main duties were contributing to scientific projects, active participation at international conferences and teaching business students.

title: Intern
description_1: Part of the supervision of non-bank financial institutions in April and May 2015. My tasks included evaluating data for insurance sector stress testing and compiling reports pertainting to financial stability .

title: Research Assistant
description_1: I updated a project on social security fraud in the Austrian construction sector in February and March 2015.

title: Intern
description_1: Part of the portfolio advisory team from November 2014 to January 2015. I compiled reports for debt restructuring negotiations and translated code for pricing of collateralized debt obligations.

title: Research Assistant
description_1: Part of the labour market and social security group from May 2012 to October 2013. I maintained the in-house tax-benefit model and contributed to numerous prjects on the Autrian tax and pension system.

title: Instructor
description_1: I was an instructor for 'Liquidity Monitoring' on cryptocurrency markets.

title: Thesis Supervisor
loc: WU (Vienna University of Economics and Business)
description_1: I supervised 12 Bachelor students who wrote theses on cryptocurrency markets and interest rate modeling.

title: Tutor
description_1: I supervised students who worked on FinTech as part of the Gutman Private Wealth Management Seminar.

title: Teaching Assistant
loc: WU (Vienna University of Economics and Business)
description_1: I taught 'Linear Algebra' to business students.

title: Teaching Assistant
description_1: I taught 'Microeconomics' to mathematics students in the summer terms of 2012 and 2014.

title: Teaching Assistant
description_1: I was teaching assistant for the courses 'Calculus', 'Keynes for Beginners', 'International Macroeconomics', 'Growth, Distribution and Wage Policy' and 'Macroeconomics and Inequality'

description_1: Award for the paper 'Financing under Demand Uncertainty'.
